Starbucks goal to cut waste in half by 2.search_query: When did Starbucks announce a goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks goal to cut waste in half by 2.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks has implemented several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In 2023, Starbucks further advanced its sustainability efforts by committing over $50 million to sustainable waste and water funds, aiming to scale innovative solutions for water access and waste reduction. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-commits-over-50-million-to-sustainable-waste-and-water-funds-toward-a-resource-positive-future/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in 2024, Starbucks expanded its Greener Stores program, certifying 6,091 stores globally, nearly doubling its portfolio from the previous year. These stores focus on energy and water savings, as well as waste diversion, contributing to the company's goal of reducing waste sent to landfills by 50% by 2030. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

Through these initiatives, Starbucks continues to work toward its ambitious waste reduction target, reflecting its ongoing commitment to environmental sustainability.

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program.search_query: When was Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program piloted or launched?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program.evidence: Starbucks launched its "Borrow a Cup" program as a pilot in five Seattle stores in March 2021. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) This initiative allowed customers to borrow reusable cups for a $1 refundable deposit, aiming to reduce single-use cup waste. The program was extended to several countries, including Germany, Japan, the U.K., and Singapore, as well as to locations within the U.S. beyond Seattle. ([foodrepublic.com](https://www.foodrepublic.com/1368512/starbucks-byo-borrow-a-cup-nationwide-2024/?utm_source=openai)) By August 2023, Starbucks expanded the program to 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California, furthering its commitment to sustainability. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai))

sample_2.justification: The code uses Java generics (List<Integer>), introduced with J2SE 5.0 in 2004; therefore a model needs knowledge through 2004 to produce that specific snippet without leakage.

Java Generics (J2SE 5.0).search_query: When were generics introduced in Java (J2SE 5.0 release year)?
Java Generics (J2SE 5.0).evidence:
Generics were introduced in Java with the release of J2SE 5.0, also known as Java 2 Platform Standard Edition 5.0, on September 30, 2004. ([oracle.com](https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/javase/j2se-1-5.html?utm_source=openai)) This version, codenamed "Tiger," marked a significant upgrade to the Java platform, adding several new language features, including:

- **Generics**: Providing compile-time type safety for collections and eliminating the need for most type casts.
- **Metadata (Annotations)**: Allowing classes and methods to be tagged with additional data, which can then be processed by metadata-aware utilities.
- **Enhanced for Loop**: Simplifying iteration over collections.
- **Autoboxing/Unboxing**: Enabling automatic conversion between primitive types and their corresponding wrapper classes.
- **Enumerated Types**: Introducing a type-safe way to define sets of constants.
- **Varargs**: Allowing methods to accept a variable number of arguments.
- **Static Import**: Enabling static members of classes to be accessed without class qualification.

These enhancements aimed to improve the language's expressiveness and developer productivity. ([oracle.com](https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/javase/j2se-1-5.html?utm_source=openai))

Java Collections Framework.search_query: When was the Java Collections Framework introduced (JDK 1.2 release year)?
Java Collections Framework.evidence: The Java Collections Framework was introduced in JDK 1.2, which was released on December 8, 1998. ([javapapers.com](https://javapapers.com/core-java/java-features-and-history/?utm_source=openai)) This framework provided a standardized set of interfaces and classes for data structures like `List`, `Set`, and `Map`, significantly enhancing the efficiency and flexibility of data manipulation in Java. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_collections_framework?utm_source=openai))

Bullet drop mechanic prominence in Call.search_query: When did bullet drop become a prominent mechanic in Call of Duty (Blackout or Warzone)?
Bullet drop mechanic prominence in Call.evidence:
Bullet drop became a prominent mechanic in Call of Duty with the introduction of the Blackout mode in Call of Duty: Black Ops 4, released in October 2018. Unlike traditional Call of Duty multiplayer modes that utilized hitscan mechanics—where bullets travel instantly to their target—Blackout incorporated projectile ballistics, requiring players to account for bullet travel time and drop, especially at longer distances. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

This mechanic was further emphasized during the Black Ops 4 Multiplayer Beta in August 2018, where Treyarch tested a new ballistics system that included bullet drop. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

In Call of Duty: Warzone, released in March 2020, bullet drop was also implemented. Since Warzone was developed using the same engine as Modern Warfare, the game's weapons and ballistics behaved similarly, including the presence of bullet drop. ([gamerevolution.com](https://www.gamerevolution.com/guides/640029-does-warzone-have-bullet-drop?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, bullet drop became a significant mechanic in Call of Duty starting with Blackout in 2018 and continued in Warzone in 2020.

Bullet drop mechanic prominence in Call.search_query: When did bullet drop become a prominent mechanic in Call of Duty (Blackout or Warzone)?
Bullet drop mechanic prominence in Call.evidence:
Bullet drop became a prominent mechanic in Call of Duty with the introduction of the Blackout mode in Call of Duty: Black Ops 4, released in October 2018. Unlike traditional Call of Duty multiplayer modes that utilized hitscan mechanics—where bullets travel instantly in a straight line—Blackout incorporated projectile ballistics, requiring players to account for bullet travel time and drop over distance. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

In Blackout, the extent of bullet drop varied depending on the weapon and ammunition type. Higher-caliber weapons, such as sniper rifles, exhibited less bullet drop compared to lower-caliber firearms. Additionally, attachments like the Long Barrel could reduce bullet drop by increasing bullet speed, while suppressors had the opposite effect, causing bullets to drop more quickly. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

This mechanic was further expanded in Call of Duty: Warzone, which launched in March 2020. Warzone adopted similar projectile ballistics, requiring players to adjust their aim for bullet drop, especially at longer ranges. The game's integration with the Modern Warfare engine meant that weapon behaviors, including bullet drop, were consistent with those in Modern Warfare's multiplayer modes. ([gamerevolution.com](https://www.gamerevolution.com/guides/640029-does-warzone-have-bullet-drop?utm_source=openai))

In summary, bullet drop became a significant gameplay element starting with Blackout in 2018 and continued to be a key feature in Warzone from 2020 onward.

Bullet drop mechanic prominence in Call.search_query: When did Call of Duty introduce or popularize bullet drop mechanics (e.g., Blackout/Warzone)?
Bullet drop mechanic prominence in Call.evidence:
Call of Duty introduced bullet drop mechanics with the release of **Black Ops 4** in 2018. In this installment, the 'Blackout' battle royale mode incorporated bullet drop, requiring players to adjust their aim for long-range shots. Treyarch developer Tony Flame revealed that 'mixed ballistics' would be tested in the Black Ops 4 Multiplayer Beta, with bullet drop being a key feature in the Blackout mode. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

The implementation of bullet drop in Blackout was a significant shift from the traditional hitscan mechanics of previous Call of Duty titles, where bullets traveled instantly to their targets without any drop. This change added a new layer of realism and strategy to the gameplay, as players now had to account for bullet trajectory over longer distances.

Following Black Ops 4, the main series continued to feature bullet drop mechanics. In **Modern Warfare (2019)**, Infinity Ward introduced a new approach to weapon ballistics, incorporating bullet trajectory into the gameplay. Art director Joel Emslie explained that players would need to consider bullet drop and, in some cases, windage when firing designated marksman rifles (DMRs) or sniper rifles. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

The introduction of bullet drop mechanics in Black Ops 4 and their continued presence in subsequent titles have influenced the design of other first-person shooters, encouraging a more realistic approach to long-range combat.

Sonic the Hedgehog (character/franchise).evidence:
Sonic the Hedgehog, the iconic platform game developed by Sega, was first released in Japan on June 23, 1991. It debuted in North America on June 23, 1991, and in the United Kingdom on June 21, 1991. The game was later released in other PAL regions and Japan the following month. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonic_the_Hedgehog_%281991_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

The game's development began in 1990 when Sega aimed to create a mascot to rival Nintendo's Mario. Character designer Naoto Ohshima's blue hedgehog design won an internal contest, leading to the formation of Sonic Team. The game was officially unveiled at the Tokyo Toy Show in June 1990. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonic_the_Hedgehog_%281991_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

Sonic the Hedgehog received positive reviews for its visuals, audio, and gameplay, becoming one of the best-selling video games of its time. It sold over 40 million copies across all platforms, with over 15 million copies sold on the Genesis, making it the best-selling Genesis game. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonic_the_Hedgehog_%281991_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

Developers are encouraged to use `ContextMenuStrip` for new applications to take advantage of its enhanced features. Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF).search_query: When was Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) first released?
Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF).evidence: Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) was first released on November 21, 2006, as part of the .NET Framework 3.0. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Presentation_Foundation?utm_source=openai)) Initially codenamed "Avalon," WPF introduced a unified programming model for building rich user interfaces on Windows. It leverages XAML (Extensible Application Markup Language) for declarative UI design and supports advanced graphics, animations, and data binding. WPF is included with Windows Vista and later versions, and is also available for Windows XP Service Pack 2 and newer. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Presentation_Foundation?utm_source=openai))

.NET Framework 3.0.evidence:
The .NET Framework 3.0 was released on November 6, 2006. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.NET_Framework_version_history?utm_source=openai)) This version introduced four major components:

- **Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF):** A new user interface subsystem and API based on XAML markup language, utilizing 3D computer graphics hardware and Direct3D technologies.

- **Windows Communication Foundation (WCF):** A service-oriented messaging system that allows programs to interoperate locally or remotely, similar to web services.

- **Windows Workflow Foundation (WF):** Enables building task automation and integrated transactions using workflows.

- **Windows CardSpace:** A software component that securely stores a person's digital identities and provides a unified interface for choosing the identity for a particular transaction, such as logging into a website.

These components were designed to enhance the development of Windows applications by providing advanced features for user interfaces, communication, workflows, and identity management.

Java Generics (J2SE 5.0).search_query: When did Java add generics (Java 5 release year)?
Java Generics (J2SE 5.0).evidence:
Java introduced generics in Java SE 5, which was released on September 30, 2004. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_version_history?utm_source=openai)) This version, also known as J2SE 5.0, introduced several significant language features, including:

- **Generics**: Provides compile-time type safety for collections and eliminates the need for most typecasts.
- **Metadata (Annotations)**: Allows language constructs such as classes and methods to be tagged with additional data, which can then be processed by metadata-aware utilities.
- **Autoboxing/Unboxing**: Automatic conversions between primitive types (such as `int`) and their corresponding wrapper classes (such as `Integer`).
- **Enhanced for-loop**: Simplifies iteration over collections and arrays.
- **Varargs**: Allows methods to accept a variable number of arguments.
- **Enums**: Provides a type-safe way to define a set of constants.
- **Static Imports**: Enables importing static members of classes to avoid qualifying them with the class name.

These enhancements significantly improved code readability, type safety, and developer productivity. ([oome.org](https://oome.org/java/java-5/?utm_source=openai))

Collections.sort / Collections.reverse.search_query: When were Collections.sort and Collections.reverse added to java.util.Collections?
Collections.sort / Collections.reverse.evidence:
The `Collections.sort()` and `Collections.reverse()` methods have been part of the `java.util.Collections` class since its introduction in Java 2 (JDK 1.2), which was released in December 1998. These methods provide utility functions for sorting and reversing lists, respectively.

In Java 8 Update 20 (released in March 2015), the implementation of `Collections.sort()` was optimized. Prior to this update, `Collections.sort()` would copy the elements of the list into an array, sort that array, and then update the list in place. From Java 8u20 onwards, `Collections.sort()` defers to the `List.sort()` method, allowing for more efficient sorting, especially for lists like `ArrayList` that have their own optimized sorting algorithms. ([medium.com](https://medium.com/%40edouard.kaiser/collections-sort-the-java8u20-modification-d6a9acf96861?utm_source=openai))

The `Collections.reverse()` method has remained consistent in its functionality, reversing the order of elements in a list in place.

sample_1.justification: The answer bundle references Starbucks' waste-reduction goal toward 2030 and the 'Borrow a Cup' program, which were publicly discussed around 2019–2020; knowledge through 2020 is the safest cutoff without leakage.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce its goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In March 2024, Starbucks furthered its environmental commitment by verifying 6,091 Greener Stores across more than 40 markets globally. These stores meet standards in areas such as water stewardship, energy efficiency, and waste diversion, contributing to the company's goal of reducing waste sent to landfills by 50% by 2030. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in April 2024, Starbucks introduced redesigned cold cups that use up to 20% less plastic. This initiative aims to address the surge in plastic waste resulting from increased cold drink sales and is part of the company's broader sustainability efforts to reduce waste and carbon emissions. ([apnews.com](https://apnews.com/article/90f19ce6ff721c7bf900f1447932dcc0?utm_source=openai))


## Starbucks' Sustainability Initiatives:

Bullet drop prominence in Call of Duty (.search_query: When did bullet drop become a prominent mechanic in Call of Duty (Blackout 2018 vs Warzone 2020)?
Bullet drop prominence in Call of Duty (.evidence:
Bullet drop became a prominent mechanic in Call of Duty's Blackout mode, introduced in 2018. Unlike traditional Call of Duty multiplayer modes that use hitscan mechanics, Blackout employs projectile ballistics, requiring players to account for bullet travel time and drop, especially at longer ranges. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

In contrast, Call of Duty: Warzone, released in 2020, also incorporates bullet drop mechanics. However, during its early days, some weapons, like the SP-R 208 Marksman Rifle, experienced a bug that removed bullet drop, allowing shots to travel in a straight line. This issue was addressed in subsequent updates. ([gamerant.com](https://gamerant.com/call-of-duty-warzone-sp-r-208-no-bullet-drop-bug/?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, bullet drop was a significant feature in Blackout from its inception in 2018, while in Warzone, it became a notable mechanic after the game's release in 2020, following the resolution of initial bugs.

sample_3.justification: The question is about the Munich Agreement and the Sudetenland in 1938; all relevant facts predate 2001 so the minimum safe year is capped at 2001.

Munich Agreement (Sudetenland annexation.evidence:
The Munich Agreement, signed on September 30, 1938, was a pivotal accord between Germany, the United Kingdom, France, and Italy, which permitted Nazi Germany to annex the Sudetenland region of Czechoslovakia. This area was predominantly inhabited by ethnic Germans and held significant strategic importance due to its mountainous terrain and fortified defenses. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Munich_Agreement?utm_source=openai))

The agreement was reached after escalating tensions, with Adolf Hitler demanding the Sudetenland's cession to Germany. British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and French Prime Minister Édouard Daladier, seeking to avoid war, conceded to Hitler's demands. Czechoslovakia was not invited to the negotiations and was compelled to accept the terms. ([history.com](https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/munich-pact-signed?utm_source=openai))

The Munich Agreement stipulated that the evacuation of the Sudetenland would commence on October 1, 1938, and be completed by October 10, 1938. The Czechoslovak government was responsible for carrying out the evacuation without causing damage to existing installations. ([mzv.gov.cz](https://mzv.gov.cz/file/198473/MunichAgreement.pdf?utm_source=openai))

Despite the agreement, Hitler violated its terms in March 1939 by occupying the remaining parts of Czechoslovakia, effectively dissolving the state. This breach demonstrated the failure of the Munich Agreement to prevent further German expansion and is often cited as a classic example of the policy of appeasement. ([history.com](https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/munich-pact-signed?utm_source=openai))

Fio, the Flexible I/O Tester, was developed by Jens Axboe to facilitate flexible testing of the Linux I/O subsystem and schedulers. ([github.com](https://github.com/axboe/fio?utm_source=openai))

The initial release of fio was in 2006. Axboe announced the project on September 5, 2006, stating that he was "tired of writing specific test applications to simulate a given workload" and found that existing I/O benchmark tools were not flexible enough for his needs. ([github.com](https://github.com/axboe/fio?utm_source=openai))

Since its inception, fio has undergone continuous development, with numerous updates and enhancements to support a wide range of I/O engines and benchmarking options. That same year, George Weah of Liberia became the first non-European to win the Ballon d'Or, marking a significant milestone in football history. Weah's victory was a landmark achievement, as he was the first African player to receive the Ballon d'Or. ([bitbol.co](https://www.bitbol.co/english/ballon-dor-george-weah-bitbol/?utm_source=openai))

Prior to this rule change, the Ballon d'Or was restricted to European players, which meant that footballers from other continents, including Africa and South America, were ineligible for the award. The 1995 adjustment opened the door for players from around the world to be recognized for their talents in European football. ([historyofsoccer.info](https://historyofsoccer.info/why-didnt-pele-win-the-ballon-dor?utm_source=openai))

Weah's achievement not only highlighted his individual brilliance but also paved the way for greater recognition of non-European players in European football. Morgan dollar (United States dollar coin.search_query: Morgan dollar minted from 1878 to 1904 and again in 1921
Morgan dollar (United States dollar coin.evidence:
The Morgan silver dollar is a U.S. coin minted from 1878 to 1904, with a one-year production in 1921. Designed by George T. Morgan, the coin features Lady Liberty on the obverse and a heraldic eagle on the reverse. It was produced at several U.S. Mint facilities:

- **Philadelphia**: No mint mark.
- **New Orleans**: Mint mark "O".
- **San Francisco**: Mint mark "S".
- **Carson City**: Mint mark "CC".
- **Denver**: Mint mark "D" (only in 1921).

The coin's composition is 90% silver and 10% copper, with a weight of 26.73 grams and a diameter of 38.1 mm. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morgan_dollar?utm_source=openai))

In 1921, the Denver Mint produced over 20 million Morgan dollars, more than all 13 years of Carson City mintages combined. ([bendcoinclub.org](https://bendcoinclub.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/05/Morgan_Dollars.pdf?utm_source=openai))

In 2021, the U.S. Mint resumed production of the Morgan dollar as a non-circulating collectible, striking coins in 99.9% pure silver. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morgan_dollar?utm_source=openai))

The Morgan dollar remains a popular coin among collectors due to its historical significance and distinctive design.

Coinage Act of 1873.evidence: The Coinage Act of 1873 was enacted on February 12, 1873, and became effective on April 1, 1873. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coinage_Act_of_1873?utm_source=openai))

Morgan, the Mint's Chief Engraver at the time. ([usmint.gov](https://www.usmint.gov/news/inside-the-mint/celebrating-the-iconic-morgan-and-peace-silver-dollars?utm_source=openai)) In 1878, the Philadelphia Mint produced over 10.5 million Morgan dollars, while the San Francisco Mint minted approximately 9.8 million, and the Carson City Mint produced about 2.2 million. The Morgan silver dollar was minted in 1878, 1904, and 1921, each year featuring coins from different U.S. Mint facilities. Here's a breakdown of the mintage figures for these years:

**1878:**
- **Philadelphia Mint:** 10,508,800 coins
- **San Francisco Mint:** 9,774,000 coins
- **Carson City Mint:** 2,212,000 coins

**1904:**
- **Philadelphia Mint:** 2,788,000 coins

- **San Francisco Mint:** 2,304,000 coins

**1921:**
- **Philadelphia Mint:** 44,690,000 coins
- **San Francisco Mint:** 21,695,000 coins
- **Denver Mint:** 20,345,000 coins

These figures indicate the number of coins produced at each mint during these years. Notably, the 1921 mintage saw production at the Denver Mint, which was unique for that year. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morgan_dollar?utm_source=openai))

The Morgan dollar, designed by George T. Morgan, was minted from 1878 to 1904, with a brief production in 1921. It was composed of 90% silver and 10% copper, weighing approximately 26.73 grams. The coin features Lady Liberty on the obverse and an eagle on the reverse. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morgan_dollar?utm_source=openai))

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce a goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In subsequent years, Starbucks has made significant progress toward this goal. By April 2023, the company had certified 3,508 Greener Stores globally, expanding the program to 20 markets. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-verifies-3500-greener-stores-globally/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, in March 2024, Starbucks announced the certification of 6,091 Greener Stores worldwide, nearly doubling its portfolio in the past year. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

These efforts reflect Starbucks' ongoing commitment to sustainability and its ambitious target of halving waste by 2030.

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When did Starbucks launch or announce the 'Borrow a Cup' program?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks introduced its "Borrow a Cup" program in March 2021, initiating a pilot in five Seattle stores. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) This program allowed customers to borrow reusable cups for a $1 refundable deposit, aiming to reduce single-use cup waste. The initiative was part of Starbucks' broader commitment to sustainability, with each borrowed cup intended to replace up to 30 disposable cups. ([geekwire.com](https://www.geekwire.com/2021/starbucks-trying-reusable-cups-cut-waste-teaming-seattle-recycling-startup/?utm_source=openai))

Following the success of the Seattle pilot, Starbucks expanded the program to other locations. In January 2022, the company launched the "Borrow a Cup" program in Singapore across three stores, running from January to May 2022. Call of Duty bullet drop as a notable me.search_query: When did Call of Duty introduce bullet drop in Blackout or Warzone?
Call of Duty bullet drop as a notable me.evidence:
Call of Duty introduced bullet drop mechanics in its battle royale modes with the release of **Blackout** in **Call of Duty: Black Ops 4** on October 12, 2018. In Blackout, bullets behave as projectiles, exhibiting travel time and drop-off over distance, requiring players to adjust their aim for long-range engagements. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

Following Blackout, **Warzone** was launched on March 10, 2020, as a standalone battle royale mode for **Call of Duty: Modern Warfare**. Warzone adopted similar ballistics mechanics, incorporating bullet drop to enhance realism and strategic depth in long-range combat. ([gamerevolution.com](https://www.gamerevolution.com/guides/640029-does-warzone-have-bullet-drop?utm_source=openai))

In both modes, bullet drop is influenced by factors such as ammunition type and weapon attachments. Higher-caliber rounds generally travel faster and drop less than lower-caliber ones. Attachments like the Long Barrel can increase bullet speed and reduce drop, while suppressors may decrease bullet speed and increase drop. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

Understanding and compensating for bullet drop is crucial for effective sniping and long-range engagements in both Blackout and Warzone.

Optical levitation by radiation pressure.search_query: stable levitation of small transparent glass spheres by radiation pressure 1 Torr 250 mW TEM00 cw laser year
Optical levitation by radiation pressure.evidence:
In 1971, Arthur Ashkin and J. M. Dziedzic demonstrated the stable levitation of small transparent glass spheres using radiation pressure. They achieved this by focusing a continuous-wave (cw) laser beam with a power of approximately 250 milliwatts (mW) in the TEM₀₀ mode onto a 20-micrometer (µm) diameter glass sphere. This setup allowed the sphere to remain suspended in air and vacuum environments down to pressures of about 1 Torr. ([scribd.com](https://www.scribd.com/document/403934189/Series-in-optics-and-optoelectronics-CRC-Press-Molloy-Justin-McGloin-David-Padgett-Miles-J-Optical-tweezers-methods-and-applications-Taylor?utm_source=openai))

The key to this levitation lies in the balance between the upward force exerted by the laser's radiation pressure and the downward gravitational force acting on the sphere. By carefully adjusting the laser's intensity and focusing conditions, the researchers were able to achieve a stable equilibrium, allowing the glass sphere to hover without physical support.

This pioneering work laid the foundation for the field of optical trapping and tweezers, enabling precise manipulation of microscopic particles using light. Over the years, advancements in laser technology and optical systems have further refined these techniques, leading to applications in various scientific disciplines, including physics, biology, and materials science.

Li et al. observation of instantaneous/b.search_query: Li et al. instantaneous velocity Brownian motion optically trapped particle in vacuum year published
Li et al. observation of instantaneous/b.evidence:
The study you're referring to is titled "Measurement of the instantaneous velocity of a Brownian particle" by Tongcang Li, Simon Kheifets, David Medellin, and Mark Raizen. It was published in the journal *Science* in 2010. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20488989/?utm_source=openai))

In this groundbreaking research, the team successfully measured the instantaneous velocity of a Brownian particle—a glass microsphere—trapped in air using optical tweezers. This experiment provided direct verification of Einstein's equipartition theorem and offered insights into the ballistic regime of Brownian motion, contrasting with the usual diffusive regime. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20488989/?utm_source=openai))

The publication date of this study is 2010.

Observation of instantaneous velocity of.search_query: shot-noise-limited high-bandwidth measurements instantaneous velocity Brownian motion in a liquid optical tweezer year
Observation of instantaneous velocity of.evidence:
In 2010, researchers at the University of Texas at Austin achieved shot-noise-limited, high-bandwidth measurements of the instantaneous velocity of Brownian motion in liquids using optical tweezers. They trapped micrometer-sized beads in water and acetone, observing the hydrodynamic instantaneous velocity of Brownian motion. Their findings confirmed a modified energy equipartition theorem that accounts for the kinetic energy of the fluid displaced by the moving bead and revealed an anticorrelated thermal force, which was conventionally assumed to be uncorrelated. ([raizenlab.ph.utexas.edu](https://raizenlab.ph.utexas.edu/pub/kheifets_science.pdf?utm_source=openai))

This work provided direct verification of Einstein's energy equipartition theorem for a Brownian particle and observed the ballistic regime of Brownian motion at short times, contrasting with the usual diffusive regime. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20488989/?utm_source=openai))

These advancements have significant implications for understanding microscopic dynamics in soft condensed matter and have paved the way for future tests of statistical mechanics at the quantum level. ([optics.org](https://optics.org/article/42726?utm_source=openai))

Instantaneous velocity of Brownian motio.search_query: Li Raizen Brownian motion instantaneous velocity vacuum 2010
Instantaneous velocity of Brownian motio.evidence:
In 2010, physicist Mark Raizen and his team at the University of Texas at Austin, including Tongcang Li, Simon Kheifets, and David Medellin, achieved a significant breakthrough by directly measuring the instantaneous velocity of a Brownian particle. This experiment provided the first direct verification of Einstein's equipartition theorem for Brownian particles. ([news.utexas.edu](https://news.utexas.edu/2010/05/20/physicists-prove-einstein-wrong-with-observation-of-instantaneous-velocity-in-brownian-particles/?utm_source=openai))

To conduct this experiment, the researchers trapped a micrometer-sized glass bead in air using an optical tweezer—a technique that employs laser beams to suspend particles. By analyzing the bead's motion over a wide range of pressures, they were able to measure its instantaneous velocity. This observation confirmed the transition from the ballistic regime, where particles move in straight lines, to the diffusive regime, where their motion becomes random due to collisions with surrounding molecules. ([chaos.utexas.edu](https://chaos.utexas.edu/publications/measurement-of-the-instantaneous-velocity-of-a-brownian-particle?utm_source=openai))

The findings not only validated Einstein's theoretical predictions but also opened avenues for future experiments aimed at cooling the center-of-mass motion of a bead in a vacuum to its quantum ground state. ([chaos.utexas.edu](https://chaos.utexas.edu/publications/measurement-of-the-instantaneous-velocity-of-a-brownian-particle?utm_source=openai))

For a detailed account of this research, you can refer to the original publication:

- Li, T., Kheifets, S., Medellin, D., & Raizen, M. G. (2010). Measurement of the Instantaneous Velocity of a Brownian Particle. *Science*, 328(5986), 1673–1675. ([chaos.utexas.edu](https://chaos.utexas.edu/publications/measurement-of-the-instantaneous-velocity-of-a-brownian-particle?utm_source=openai))

This study represents a pivotal moment in the field of statistical mechanics, bridging a century-old theoretical prediction with experimental reality.

Instantaneous velocity of Brownian motio.search_query: hydrodynamic instantaneous velocity of Brownian motion in a liquid optical tweezer 2011 2012 2013
Instantaneous velocity of Brownian motio.evidence:
The study of Brownian motion in liquids using optical tweezers has advanced significantly between 2011 and 2013, particularly concerning the measurement of instantaneous velocities and the understanding of hydrodynamic interactions.

In 2011, researchers at the University of Texas at Austin achieved a groundbreaking measurement of the instantaneous velocity of a Brownian particle suspended in air using optical tweezers. This experiment provided direct verification of the energy equipartition theorem and observed the transition from ballistic to diffusive motion in the particle's dynamics. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20488989/?utm_source=openai))

Building upon this work, a 2012 study developed an in situ method to calibrate optical tweezers experiments and simultaneously measure the size of the trapped particle or the viscosity of the surrounding fluid. By recording the positional fluctuations of the trapped particle with a high-bandwidth photodetector, the researchers computed the mean-square displacement and the velocity autocorrelation function, comparing them to theoretical models of Brownian motion that include hydrodynamic memory effects. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1208.1114?utm_source=openai))

In 2013, another significant advancement was made with the direct measurement of colloidal hydrodynamics near flat boundaries using oscillating optical tweezers. This study focused on colloidal particles near fluid-fluid interfaces, such as liquid-vapor and liquid-liquid interfaces, and provided quantitative measurements of the anisotropic hydrodynamic mobility of a colloidal particle by tracking its thermal motion in an optical trap located near these interfaces. ([sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0378437113003270?utm_source=openai))

Collectively, these studies have enhanced our understanding of Brownian motion in liquids, particularly in the context of optical tweezers, by providing direct measurements of instantaneous velocities and elucidating the role of hydrodynamic interactions in particle dynamics.

- **Generics**: Providing compile-time type safety for collections and eliminating the need for most type casts.
- **Enhanced for Loop**: Simplifying iteration over collections.
- **Autoboxing/Unboxing**: Automatically converting between primitive types and their corresponding wrapper classes.
- **Enumerations**: Defining a set of named constants.
- **Varargs**: Allowing methods to accept a variable number of arguments.
- **Static Import**: Enabling the import of static members of classes.
- **Metadata (Annotations)**: Adding metadata to Java code for various purposes.

These enhancements significantly improved developer productivity and the overall performance of Java applications. ([oracle.com](https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/jsp-j2se.html?utm_source=openai))

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce a goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks has implemented several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In 2023, Starbucks further advanced its sustainability efforts by committing over $50 million to sustainable waste and water funds, aiming to scale innovative solutions for water access and waste reduction. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-commits-over-50-million-to-sustainable-waste-and-water-funds-toward-a-resource-positive-future/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in 2024, Starbucks expanded its Greener Stores program, certifying 6,091 stores globally, nearly doubling its portfolio from the previous year. These stores focus on energy and water savings, as well as waste diversion, contributing to the company's goal of reducing waste sent to landfills by 50% by 2030. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

Through these initiatives, Starbucks continues to work toward its ambitious waste reduction target, reflecting its ongoing commitment to environmental sustainability.

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program.search_query: When was Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program piloted or launched?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program.evidence:
Starbucks launched its "Borrow a Cup" program as a pilot in five Seattle stores in March 2021. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) This initiative allowed customers to borrow reusable cups for a $1 refundable deposit, aiming to reduce single-use cup waste. The program ran through May 31, 2021. ([foodnetwork.com](https://www.foodnetwork.com/fn-dish/news/starbucks-reusable-cup-program-borrow-a-cup-seattle?utm_source=openai))

Following the success of the Seattle pilot, Starbucks expanded the "Borrow a Cup" program to other locations. In January 2022, the program was introduced in Singapore across three stores at the National University of Singapore, running from January to May 2022. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai)) By November 2022, the program had been implemented in 60 stores in Taiwan, with plans to expand to all stores nationwide by the end of 2023. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-offers-borrow-a-cup-program-at-sixty-stores-in-taiwan/?utm_source=openai))

In August 2023, Starbucks launched a reusable cup test in 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California, as part of its sustainability efforts. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai)) These initiatives reflect Starbucks' ongoing commitment to reducing waste and promoting sustainability through reusable cup programs.

Bullet drop as a prominent mechanic in C.search_query: When did bullet drop become a major mechanic in Call of Duty (Blackout or Warzone)?
Bullet drop as a prominent mechanic in C.evidence:
Bullet drop became a significant mechanic in Call of Duty's Blackout mode, introduced in Black Ops 4, released in October 2018. This was a departure from the traditional hitscan mechanics of previous Call of Duty titles, where bullets traveled instantly to their target. In Blackout, bullets act as projectiles with travel time and drop-off, requiring players to lead shots and aim higher at longer distances. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

The inclusion of bullet drop in Blackout was part of a broader effort to enhance realism and strategic depth in the game. Treyarch developer Tony Flame revealed that the studio was implementing 'mixed ballistics' in the Black Ops 4 Beta, with bullet drop being a key component of this system. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

In Warzone, released in March 2020, bullet drop mechanics were also incorporated, aligning with the game's realistic approach to weapon handling. This meant that, similar to Blackout, players needed to account for bullet travel time and drop when engaging targets at long distances. ([gamerevolution.com](https://www.gamerevolution.com/guides/640029-does-warzone-have-bullet-drop?utm_source=openai))

Overall, the introduction of bullet drop in Blackout marked a significant shift in Call of Duty's gameplay, emphasizing the need for players to master new shooting mechanics, especially in long-range engagements.

2023 up-to-date Virgin Islands travel gu.search_query: What transportation options and operators were current in 2023 for getting around the US Virgin Islands and British Virgin Islands?
2023 up-to-date Virgin Islands travel gu.evidence:
In 2023, both the U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI) and the British Virgin Islands (BVI) offered a variety of transportation options to facilitate travel within and between the islands.

**U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI):**

- **Public Transportation:** The Virgin Islands Territorial Emergency Management Agency (VITEMA) operates the VITRAN bus system, providing service across the islands. As of late 2025, two buses were actively running on St. Croix, with plans to expand service. ([dpw.vi.gov](https://dpw.vi.gov/usvi-comprehensive-transportation-plan/?utm_source=openai))

- **Ferries:** Regular ferry services connect the main islands, including routes between St. Thomas and St. John, as well as between St. Croix and St. Thomas. ([visitusvi.com](https://www.visitusvi.com/travel-information/transportation/?utm_source=openai))

- **Taxis and Car Rentals:** Taxis are readily available, with fares regulated per person. Car rental agencies operate on the islands, offering vehicles suitable for various terrains. ([visitusvi.com](https://www.visitusvi.com/travel-information/transportation/?utm_source=openai))

- **Water Taxis:** Private water taxi services are available for inter-island travel, providing flexible schedules and personalized service. ([crewedyachtsbvi.com](https://www.crewedyachtsbvi.com/getting-here?utm_source=openai))

**British Virgin Islands (BVI):**

- **Ferries:** Ferries are the primary mode of inter-island transportation, with companies like Inter Island Ferry, Speedy’s, and New Horizon Ferry offering regular services between Tortola, Virgin Gorda, Jost Van Dyke, and Anegada. ([nomadicmatt.com](https://www.nomadicmatt.com/travel-guides/caribbean-travel-tips/british-virgin-islands/?utm_source=openai))

Cyril E. King Airport (St. Thomas, STT).search_query: When was Cyril E. King Airport (STT) established or opened?
Cyril E. King Airport (St. Thomas, STT).evidence:
Cyril E. King Airport (STT) in St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands, has a rich history that reflects its evolution from a military airstrip to a modern international airport.

**Early Development:**
- **1927:** The area now known as Mosquito Bay was established as an airstrip, serving as the only facility for St. Thomas.
- **1928:** The first passengers landed at this airstrip.
- **1935:** The U.S. government purchased the airstrip, renaming it Bourne Field after the first person to fly non-stop from the United States to Nicaragua.
- **1940:** The U.S. Navy expanded the base, extending and paving the runways to accommodate military operations during World War II.

**Transition to Civilian Use:**
- **1946:** After World War II, the base was handed over to civilian authorities.
- **1950:** The Department of the Interior leased the land to the Virgin Islands government for civilian use.
- **1954:** The lease was canceled due to administrative issues, and the property was transferred to the U.S. Virgin Islands Corporation.

**Naming and Terminal Development:**
- **1984:** The airport was renamed Cyril E. King Airport in honor of the second elected governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands.
- **1990:** A new passenger terminal was completed, marking a significant upgrade in facilities.

This progression highlights the airport's transformation from a military airstrip to a key hub in the Caribbean, serving both civilian and military needs over the decades.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.search_query: When did Starbucks announce its goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/5-things-to-know-about-starbucks-new-environmental-sustainability-commitment?utm_source=openai))

In subsequent years, Starbucks has made significant progress toward this goal. By April 2023, the company had certified 3,508 Greener Stores globally, expanding the program to 20 markets. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-verifies-3500-greener-stores-globally/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, in March 2024, Starbucks announced the verification of 6,091 Greener Stores worldwide, nearly doubling its portfolio in the past year. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

These efforts reflect Starbucks' ongoing commitment to sustainability and its ambitious target of halving waste by 2030.

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.search_query: When was the Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program launched or piloted?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' pilot.evidence:
Starbucks initiated its "Borrow a Cup" program in March 2021 with a pilot in five Seattle stores. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) This program allowed customers to borrow reusable cups for a $1 refundable deposit, aiming to reduce single-use cup waste. The pilot ran until May 31, 2021. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai))

Following the success of the Seattle pilot, Starbucks expanded the program internationally. In January 2022, the company launched the "Borrow a Cup" program in Singapore across three stores, running from January to May 2022. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai)) By November 2022, the program had been implemented in 60 stores in Taiwan, with plans to expand to all stores nationwide by the end of 2023. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-offers-borrow-a-cup-program-at-sixty-stores-in-taiwan/?utm_source=openai))

In August 2023, Starbucks further expanded the program to 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California, continuing its commitment to sustainability. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai))

These initiatives reflect Starbucks' ongoing efforts to promote sustainability and reduce waste through reusable cup programs.

Java Generics.search_query: When were generics introduced in Java (J2SE 5.0)?
Java Generics.evidence: Generics were introduced in Java with the release of J2SE 5.0 (also known as Java 1.5) in September 2004. ([docs.oracle.com](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/extra/generics/intro.html?utm_source=openai)) This addition allowed developers to write more flexible and reusable code while maintaining type safety. Prior to this, collections in Java used the `Object` type to store elements, necessitating explicit casting and deferring type safety checks to runtime, which could lead to `ClassCastException` errors if types mismatched. ([grokipedia.com](https://grokipedia.com/page/Generics_in_Java?utm_source=openai))

Bullet drop mechanic prominence in Call.search_query: When did Call of Duty implement or popularize bullet drop mechanics (e.g., Blackout 2018, Warzone 2020)?
Bullet drop mechanic prominence in Call.evidence:
Call of Duty introduced bullet drop mechanics in its 2018 release, *Call of Duty: Black Ops 4*, specifically within the Blackout battle royale mode. This feature was highlighted during the game's beta phase, with Treyarch developer Tony Flame revealing that "mixed ballistics" would be tested, incorporating bullet drop on certain weapons. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

In Blackout, bullets behave as projectiles with travel time and drop-off, requiring players to adjust their aim for long-range engagements. The extent of bullet drop varies depending on weapon type and ammunition caliber. For instance, higher-caliber weapons like sniper rifles exhibit less drop compared to lower-caliber ones. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

Following Blackout, the main multiplayer mode of *Black Ops 4* did not implement bullet drop mechanics, maintaining the series' traditional hitscan system where bullets travel instantly to their target. However, in the 2019 release, *Call of Duty: Modern Warfare*, Infinity Ward incorporated bullet drop into the campaign mode, particularly for designated marksman rifles (DMRs) and sniper rifles. Art director Joel Emslie explained that players would need to account for bullet trajectory, including drop and windage, when using these weapons. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

The 2020 release, *Call of Duty: Warzone*, continued this trend by including bullet drop mechanics, especially affecting weapons with shorter ranges like SMGs and shotguns. Long-range weapons, such as sniper rifles, exhibit less bullet drop, allowing for more accurate shots over extended distances. ([gamerevolution.com](https://www.gamerevolution.com/guides/640029-does-warzone-have-bullet-drop?utm_source=openai))

In summary, Call of Duty popularized bullet drop mechanics with the introduction of Blackout in 2018, and this feature has since been incorporated into subsequent titles like *Modern Warfare* and *Warzone*.

Jake Paul (YouTuber/public figure).search_query: When did Jake Paul become widely known as a YouTuber or public figure (Vine/YouTube/Disney timeframe)?
Jake Paul (YouTuber/public figure).evidence:
Jake Paul first gained widespread recognition as a public figure in 2013 when he began posting comedic videos on Vine, a platform known for its six-second looping clips. His engaging content quickly amassed a substantial following, and by the time Vine was discontinued in 2016, he had garnered over 5 million followers and more than 2 billion views. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jake_Paul?utm_source=openai))

In 2014, Paul expanded his online presence by launching his YouTube channel, which became known for pranks, controversies, and his hip-hop music. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jake_Paul?utm_source=openai))

His success on social media led to mainstream opportunities, including a role on the Disney Channel series "Bizaardvark," where he portrayed Dirk Mann from 2016 to 2017. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jake_Paul?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, Jake Paul's rise to prominence as a YouTuber and public figure occurred between 2013 and 2016, during his time on Vine, YouTube, and Disney Channel.

Starbucks goal to cut waste in half by 2.search_query: When did Starbucks announce its goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks goal to cut waste in half by 2.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In subsequent years, Starbucks has made significant progress toward these goals. By April 2023, the company had certified 3,508 Greener Stores globally, expanding the program to 20 markets. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-verifies-3500-greener-stores-globally/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, in March 2024, Starbucks announced the verification of 6,091 Greener Stores worldwide, nearly doubling its portfolio in the past year. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

These efforts reflect Starbucks' ongoing commitment to sustainability and its ambitious target of halving waste by 2030.

Call of Duty franchise (first release).search_query: When was the first Call of Duty game released?
Call of Duty franchise (first release).evidence:
The first *Call of Duty* game was released on October 29, 2003, for Microsoft Windows. Developed by Infinity Ward and published by Activision, it is a first-person shooter that simulates infantry and combined arms warfare during World War II. The game offers multiple perspectives, including American, British, and Soviet campaigns in Europe. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty_%28video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

Since then, the *Call of Duty* franchise has expanded significantly, with numerous sequels and spin-offs. The most recent installment, *Call of Duty: Black Ops 7*, was released on November 14, 2025. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Black_Ops_7?utm_source=openai))

Call of Duty: Warzone.search_query: When was Call of Duty: Warzone released?
Call of Duty: Warzone.evidence:
Call of Duty: Warzone was initially released on March 10, 2020, as a free-to-play battle royale game for PlayStation 4, Windows, and Xbox One. It was developed by Raven Software and Infinity Ward, and published by Activision. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone?utm_source=openai))

A successor, initially titled Call of Duty: Warzone 2.0, was released on November 16, 2022, as part of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II. This version was later renamed simply Call of Duty: Warzone. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone_%282022_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

A mobile adaptation, Call of Duty: Warzone Mobile, was released on March 21, 2024. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty?utm_source=openai))

In June 2023, Activision announced that the original Warzone servers would be shut down on September 21, 2023, to focus development on Warzone 2.0. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone?utm_source=openai))

As of January 2026, Call of Duty: Warzone 2.0 remains active, with ongoing updates and content additions.

For a visual overview, you might enjoy the launch trailer for the original Verdansk map:

[Verdansk Launch Trailer | Call of Duty: Warzone](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pqPCFUUbMiU&utm_source=openai)

Bullet drop as a prominent mechanic in C.search_query: When did bullet drop become a prominent mechanic in Call of Duty (e.g., Blackout/Warzone)?
Bullet drop as a prominent mechanic in C.evidence:
Bullet drop, the downward trajectory of a bullet over distance due to gravity, became a prominent mechanic in Call of Duty with the introduction of the battle royale mode, Blackout, in *Call of Duty: Black Ops 4* (2018). This mode featured expansive maps and longer engagement ranges, necessitating players to account for bullet drop, especially when using sniper rifles. For instance, sniper rifles like the Outlaw, Koshka, Paladin, and SDM exhibited the least bullet drop, while SMGs and pistols had more pronounced drop-offs. ([charlieintel.com](https://www.charlieintel.com/call-of-duty/bullet-drop-breakdown-for-blackout-in-black-ops-4-50187/?utm_source=openai))

The mechanic was further emphasized in *Call of Duty: Warzone* (2020), where the large map size and long-range combat made bullet drop a significant factor. In Warzone, bullet drop becomes noticeable at distances over 200 to 300 meters, requiring players to aim above their targets to compensate. ([thegamer.com](https://www.thegamer.com/call-of-duty-warzone-bullet-drop-guide/?utm_source=openai))

Prior to these titles, traditional Call of Duty multiplayer modes did not incorporate bullet drop, focusing instead on more immediate, close-quarters combat. The introduction of bullet drop in Blackout marked a shift towards more realistic ballistics in the series, aligning with the genre's emphasis on long-range engagements.

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program.search_query: When was Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' reusable cup program first piloted or launched?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program.evidence:
Starbucks first launched its "Borrow a Cup" reusable cup program in March 2021, piloting it in five Seattle stores. ([seattle.eater.com](https://seattle.eater.com/2021/4/7/22372019/starbucks-pilot-program-borrow-a-cup-starts-in-seattle?utm_source=openai)) The program allowed customers to borrow a reusable cup for a $1 refundable deposit, with the option to return it within two months for a $1 in-store credit and ten bonus stars for Starbucks Rewards members. ([foodrepublic.com](https://www.foodrepublic.com/1368512/starbucks-byo-borrow-a-cup-nationwide-2024/?utm_source=openai))

Following the success of this initial trial, Starbucks expanded the program to other locations. In January 2022, the company introduced the "Borrow a Cup" program at three stores in Singapore, aiming to encourage customers to shift away from single-use cups. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai)) By November 2022, the program had been implemented across 60 stores in Taiwan, with plans to extend it to all stores nationwide by the end of 2023. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-offers-borrow-a-cup-program-at-sixty-stores-in-taiwan/?utm_source=openai)) In August 2023, Starbucks launched a reusable cup test in 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California, further advancing its sustainability efforts. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2023/starbucks-latest-california-borrow-a-cup-test-furthers-companys-shift-toward-reusables/?utm_source=openai))

Bullet drop as a prominent mechanic in C.search_query: When did bullet drop become a gameplay mechanic in Call of Duty (Blackout or Warzone)?
Bullet drop as a prominent mechanic in C.evidence:
Bullet drop was introduced as a gameplay mechanic in Call of Duty's Blackout mode, which debuted in 2018 as part of Call of Duty: Black Ops 4. This feature was highlighted during the game's beta phase, with Treyarch developer Tony Flame revealing that "mixed ballistics" would be tested, incorporating bullet drop on certain weapons. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

In Blackout, bullets behave as projectiles with travel time and drop-off, requiring players to lead targets and adjust aim for distance. The extent of bullet drop varies by weapon class and ammunition type. For instance, sniper rifles like the Outlaw, Koshka, Paladin, and SDM exhibit the least bullet drop, while SMGs and pistols experience more significant drop-off. ([charlieintel.com](https://www.charlieintel.com/call-of-duty/bullet-drop-breakdown-for-blackout-in-black-ops-4-50187/?utm_source=openai))

Call of Duty: Warzone, released in 2020, also incorporated bullet drop mechanics. Since Warzone was developed using the same engine as Modern Warfare, its weapons exhibit similar behavior, including bullet drop. ([gamerevolution.com](https://www.gamerevolution.com/guides/640029-does-warzone-have-bullet-drop?utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive understanding of bullet drop mechanics in Warzone, you might find the following video helpful:

[ULTIMATE Sniper Bullet Velocity and Bullet Drop Guide for Call Of Duty Warzone!](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4hRm1CBhweM&utm_source=openai)

Bullet drop as a prominent mechanic in C.search_query: When did bullet drop become a notable mechanic in Call of Duty (Blackout or Warzone)?
Bullet drop as a prominent mechanic in C.evidence:
Bullet drop became a notable mechanic in Call of Duty with the introduction of the Blackout mode in Call of Duty: Black Ops 4, released in October 2018. Unlike traditional Call of Duty multiplayer modes that utilized hitscan mechanics—where bullets travel instantly in a straight line—Blackout incorporated projectile ballistics, requiring players to account for bullet travel time and drop over distance. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

This mechanic was further emphasized during the game's development. In August 2018, Treyarch developer Tony Flame revealed that "mixed ballistics," including bullet drop, would be tested in the Black Ops 4 Multiplayer Beta, with full implementation in the Blackout mode. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

In Call of Duty: Warzone, released in March 2020, bullet drop was also integrated, aligning with the game's realistic ballistics system. Players needed to adjust their aim to compensate for bullet drop, especially at longer ranges. ([gamerevolution.com](https://www.gamerevolution.com/guides/640029-does-warzone-have-bullet-drop?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, bullet drop became a significant gameplay element starting with Blackout in 2018 and continued in Warzone in 2020.

Starbucks waste-cut goal by 2030.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to cut waste in half by 2030 on January 21, 2020. In a public letter, CEO Kevin Johnson outlined the company's multi-decade aspiration to become "resource positive," aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. The preliminary targets for 2030 included a 50% reduction in waste sent to landfills from stores and manufacturing. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this, Starbucks committed to several strategies, such as expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable agricultural practices and waste management. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/5-things-to-know-about-starbucks-new-environmental-sustainability-commitment?utm_source=openai))

Since then, Starbucks has been actively working toward these goals, including the certification of over 3,500 Greener Stores globally by April 2023, which incorporate sustainable features to reduce environmental impact. Call of Duty bullet drop prominence (Bla.search_query: When did bullet drop become a notable mechanic in Call of Duty (Blackout or Warzone)?
Call of Duty bullet drop prominence (Bla.evidence:
Bullet drop became a notable mechanic in Call of Duty with the introduction of the Blackout mode in Call of Duty: Black Ops 4, released in October 2018. Unlike traditional Call of Duty multiplayer modes that utilized hitscan mechanics—where bullets travel instantly in a straight line—Blackout incorporated projectile ballistics, requiring players to account for bullet travel time and drop, especially at longer distances. In Call of Duty: Warzone, released in March 2020, bullet drop mechanics were also implemented. Since Warzone was developed using the same engine as Modern Warfare, the game's guns and bullets exhibited similar behavior, including bullet drop. ([gamerevolution.com](https://www.gamerevolution.com/guides/640029-does-warzone-have-bullet-drop?utm_source=openai))

Overall, the introduction of bullet drop in Blackout and its subsequent inclusion in Warzone added a realistic and strategic element to long-range combat, challenging players to master new aiming techniques.

Art Nouveau (art movement).search_query: What years did the Art Nouveau movement span?
Art Nouveau (art movement).evidence:
The Art Nouveau movement, characterized by its organic forms and decorative arts, spanned from approximately 1890 to 1910. It emerged as a reaction against the academicism and historicism of 19th-century art and architecture. The movement reached its peak during the 1900 Paris Exposition Universelle, which showcased Art Nouveau's influence across various disciplines, including architecture, design, and decorative arts. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Nouveau?utm_source=openai))

In France, Art Nouveau was also known as "Style Moderne" or "Style 1900," reflecting its association with the turn of the century. The movement's popularity began to decline by 1910 and virtually disappeared by 1914, coinciding with the onset of World War I. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Nouveau?utm_source=openai))

In summary, Art Nouveau flourished from the early 1890s until the outbreak of World War I in 1914, with its most significant period of influence occurring between 1890 and 1910.

Yoshitaka Amano.search_query: When did Yoshitaka Amano begin his role as lead artist/illustrator for Final Fantasy (1987)?
Yoshitaka Amano.evidence:
Yoshitaka Amano began his role as the lead artist and illustrator for the Final Fantasy series in 1987. He was commissioned by Square (now Square Enix) to design the characters and overall artwork for the original Final Fantasy game. His distinctive style, characterized by fluid lines and ethereal compositions, significantly contributed to the game's unique aesthetic. ([wired.com](https://www.wired.com/2013/03/the-sky-final-fantasy/?utm_source=openai))

Amano's involvement continued through the first six installments of the series, where he served as the character designer and general artwork director. His contributions played a pivotal role in establishing the visual identity of Final Fantasy, blending traditional Japanese art influences with Western styles. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recurring_elements_in_the_Final_Fantasy_series?utm_source=openai))

After Final Fantasy VI in 1994, Amano stepped down from his role as the main character designer. However, he continued to provide promotional and character artwork for subsequent games and designed their title logos. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshitaka_Amano?utm_source=openai))

Amano's work has left an indelible mark on the Final Fantasy franchise, and his artistic influence remains evident in the series' enduring popularity.

Blender Geometry Nodes.search_query: When were Geometry Nodes introduced in Blender (version and release year)?
Blender Geometry Nodes.evidence: Geometry Nodes were introduced in Blender version 2.92, released on February 25, 2021. ([blender.org](https://www.blender.org/news/blender-2-92-release/?utm_source=openai)) This initial implementation focused on object scattering and instancing, laying the groundwork for more advanced procedural modeling capabilities in subsequent releases. ([developer.blender.org](https://developer.blender.org/docs/release_notes/2.92/geometry_nodes/?utm_source=openai))

Blender new hair system / Hair Curves.search_query: When did Blender introduce the new hair system (Hair Curves) and in which version?
Blender new hair system / Hair Curves.evidence:
Blender introduced the new hair system, known as Hair Curves, in version 3.3 LTS, released in September 2022. This system is based on the Curves object type, allowing for the creation of realistic hair, fur, and other strand-based effects. ([code.blender.org](https://code.blender.org/2022/07/the-future-of-hair-grooming/?utm_source=openai))

The Hair Curves system was further enhanced in Blender 3.5, released in April 2023, with the addition of built-in hair assets and improved integration with Geometry Nodes. ([rebusfarm.net](https://rebusfarm.net/news/blender-3-5-now-supported?utm_source=openai))

For a visual introduction to Hair Curves in Blender 3.4, you might find the following tutorial helpful:

Blender 4.x Geometry Nodes node naming c.search_query: Blender Geometry Nodes Point Distribute Point Instance Attribute Randomize replaced by Distribute Points on Faces Instance on Points Random Value release version year
Blender 4.x Geometry Nodes node naming c.evidence:
In Blender's Geometry Nodes, the `Point Distribute` and `Point Instance` nodes were replaced by the `Distribute Points on Faces` and `Instance on Points` nodes, respectively, starting from Blender version 3.0. ([geometry-nodes-overview.docs.quellenform.at](https://geometry-nodes-overview.docs.quellenform.at/en/latest/?utm_source=openai))

The `Distribute Points on Faces` node places points on the surface of the input geometry, transferring point, corner, and polygon attributes, including vertex weights and UV maps. It also generates a stable `id` attribute for each point, ensuring consistency when the mesh is deformed or the density changes. ([docs.blender.org](https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/latest/modeling/geometry_nodes/point/distribute_points_on_faces.html?utm_source=openai))

The `Instance on Points` node allows for instancing objects on the distributed points, providing more control and flexibility in the instancing process.

These changes were part of a broader redesign of the Geometry Nodes system in Blender 3.0, which introduced the 'Fields' system to make the workflow more intuitive and similar to shader nodes. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blender_%28software%29?utm_source=openai))

The Blackout mode in Black Ops 4 incorporated bullet drop mechanics, requiring players to adjust their aim for long-distance shots. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))




**Call of Duty: Warzone (2020)**  
Warzone, the battle royale mode introduced in Modern Warfare, also features bullet drop mechanics, necessitating players to lead shots and adjust for distance. ([gamerevolution.com](https://www.gamerevolution.com/guides/640029-does-warzone-have-bullet-drop?utm_source=openai))




**Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019)**  
The campaign mode of Modern Warfare introduced bullet drop mechanics, especially for sniper rifles and designated marksman rifles, requiring players to account for bullet trajectory over long distances. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))


These titles marked a shift from the traditional hitscan mechanics in Call of Duty, adding a layer of realism and strategy to long-range engagements.
